text: Atlas sound hello my needle drops
Anthony Fantan oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review atlas sound
parallax atlas sound a singer/songwriter
Bradford Cox really doesn't need an
introduction better known as a member of
the band dear hunter the indie rock neo
psychedelic band dear hunter and as deer
hunter grew with more and more fame
Atlas sound has kind of become Bradford
Cox's safe haven for some indulgent
musical experiments the previous album
he dropped logos is actually one of the
first albums I reviewed on this channel
and it's a very terrible inaccurate and
horrible review and I think since then
this this album has definitely grown on
me and I've grown to appreciate the
music of Deer Hunter even more as well I
even saw them live when I was in South
by Southwest earlier this year and man
they were quite possibly the best band
that I saw there maybe even topping Bad
Brains so I was looking forward to
parallax once I heard it was going to be
released and I gotta say if this is your
first introduction to Atlas sound maybe
one of deer hunters previous three
albums would would be a better fit or
maybe one of the previous Atlas sound
records
I'm not saying parallax is bad because
to me this album just kind of comes at a
strange time dear hunter over the course
of their career has grown a lot more
accessible especially with their last
album halcyon Digest a lot of the songs
on that LP were really poppy while still
maintaining deer hunters very
psychedelic edge and whenever I would
hear something new from Atlas sound is
coming out and that happened a lot
recently since Bradford Cox was putting
out kind of a bedroom seer
of home recorded compilations of songs
it wasn't so much an amazing musical
experience as it was kind of an
interesting look into the mind of
Bradford Cox some knob twiddling weird
beats sound escapes as well as catch
here in popular moments - Atlas sound
has kind of been a project that I've
been able to listen to and find a lot of
exotic musical thoughts parallax
I don't feel has that and it's mostly
because Bradford Cox is making a
conscious effort to come up with a
uniform sound stick to it and the sound
Bradford works with on this LP is one
that is is very unintrusive its
straightforward its oriented around
verses and choruses it's actually
reminding me a lot of the direction
Deerhunter has been going in and though
I think a lot of fans will be excited
about this to me I kind of feel like Cox
in a way has put himself in competition
with what Deer Hunter was doing on
Halcyon digest because a lot of the
songs on this LP to me personally just
kind of feel like duller more meandering
and just kind of unfinished versions of
tunes that I know if they were done in
Deer Hunter would be clearer brighter
bolder maybe fleshed out with some build
ups or segues and extra instrumentation
and a wider variety of effects not to
say it was terrible and not to say it
doesn't have its moments I feel like
there are quite a few standout tracks on
here parallax is a great song and catchy
so is the shakes the opener to this
album and I think my favorite track on
this whole LP is Monalisa but overall I
just kind of find this album really easy
to listen to but difficult to remember
no matter how many times I listened to
it and revisit it because so many of the
songs here though they do have a more
uniform style they just kind of blur
together for me I guess this style isn't
without its merits I mean you know this
record is pretty popular right now in
that real estate record
that came out earlier this year was
pretty hot too if that's the sound that
catches your ears and makes you come
back for more than by all means get into
parallax but as far as I'm concerned
I'm more into logos I'm more into the
deer hunter discography I'm feeling a
decent two strong six on this thing
liked it a little bit it's alright it's
alright with me but what do you think
